questions.text: Identify this image:
Ritodrine to prevent premature labor will cause all of the complications in mother; EXCEPT?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hypoglycemia Ritodrine is β agonist. It doesn’t cause hypoglycemia but hyperglycemia. Since it can be used as tocolytics, it can cause Hyperglycemia Hypolcalemia Tremors Tachycardia Pulm. edema Ritodrine is not used these days, the only β agonist we use now is terbutaline.

questions.text: Which hyperthyroid drug is safer during first trimester of pregnancy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Propylthiouracil Hyperthyroid drugs 1. DOC in Ist trimester propylthiouracil 2. DOC is 2nd & 3rd trimester is methimazole. 3. In newborn baby on methimazole aplasia cutis is seen.

questions.text: Which is the common duration of secondary post partum hemorrhage ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 24 hours to 12 weeks 1. 10 PPH = within 24 hours - m/c/c = atonic PPH 2. 20 PPH = 24 hours to 12 weeks m/c/c or retained placental tissue

questions.text: The legal requirement for MTP includes the 'approval of 2 doctors', Among the following, which time period best suits for this requirement?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 20-24 weeks Approval of 2 doctors is required between 20-24 weeks. For GCA >24 weeks-approval of medical board is needed (1 gynecologists/obstetrician , pediatrician and radiologist)

questions.text: WHO defines maternal death as?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Death during pregnancy and within 6 weeks of delivery The annual number of female deaths from any cause related to or aggravated by pregnancy or its management (excluding accidental or incidental causes) during pregnancy and childbirth or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of the pregnancy. A late maternal death is “the death of a woman from direct or indirect obstetric causes, more than 42 days but less than one year after termination of pregnancy”.

questions.text: Best ultrasound parameter for assessment of gestational age is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The crown-rump length (CRL) is a measurement of the embryo, usually identified at 6 to 7 weeks' gestation.17,48 The embryo is measured along its longest axis to obtain the CRL measurement (Fig. 2). Crown-rump length may be used to accurately date pregnancy between 7 and 13 weeks' gestation.

questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Outlet • We can identify forceps with the type of lock. • The lock white one blade is fitting into the other blade is called English lock. • It is the classic feature of outlet forceps (aka wrigley’s) – here. They are the shortest.

questions.text: A lady presents with blood pressure 146/90 mm HG at 34 weeks gestation. What is the next step -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Urine dipstick test Here, they are asking how we screen for pre-eclampsia done for all pregnant women • BP + urine dipstick done • If > + 2, then pt. has PE. • If high BP but no proteinuria, then gestational HTN.

questions.text: If division in zygote occur between 9-12 days after fertilisation, outcome of twins is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Monochorionic monoamniotic Monozygotic twins: - Number of chorions & amnions > Depends on the time of division Amnion : Formed on day -10 Chorion : Formed on day-8 -If the zygote in monozygotic twins divides : A) 12 days : Conjoint twins Dizygotic twins : Develop from two different zygotes > Zygotes develop their own chorion and amnion > DCDA

questions.text: Most common neonatal complication of Gestational Diabetes is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hypoglycemia The most common neonatal complication of gestational diabetes is hypoglycemia • Hyperglycemia is seen in fetus. • Newborns can also have hyaline memb. Disease (respiratory distress syndrome) due to delayed lung maturity. • Newborns can also have hypo calcemia, hypomagnesemia, polycythemia, hyperbilirubinemia and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A patient presents with positive Urine Pregnancy test. In which of the following condition we will have to assess pregnancy test repeatedly
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Molar Pregnancy In molar pregnancy, a pregnancy test will have to be done repeatedly • Although, we won’t repeat urine pregnancy test but a serum pregnancy test but a serum pregnancy test will have to be done repeatedly. • Serum HCG test will be done In molar preg. higher than expected. Complete mole>>partial mole. Patient with HCG > 105 Age > 40 B/L large thecaleution cyst Fundal ht> POG Will have high risk for GTN and they need. Prophylactic chemotherapy after suction & evacuation. (DOC = methotrexate>> achino.D)

questions.text: Identify the anomaly shown in given image:
Which maneuvre is done at the time of labour when fetal scalp is visible at vulva
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ritgen The question describes a situation during labor when the fetal scalp is visible at the vulva, which indicates the crowning stage of delivery. At this point, controlled delivery of the fetal head is crucial to prevent perineal tears in the mother and intracranial injury to the baby. The image also visually suggests support being given to the fetal head. The Ritgen maneuver (B) is a technique used during the delivery of the fetal head. It involves applying pressure to the fetal chin through the perineum just in front of the coccyx, while simultaneously exerting pressure on the occiput (back of the head) to help extend the head and control its expulsion. This maneuver helps to deliver the head slowly and protect the perineum. Now, let's analyze why the other options are incorrect: A. Pinard maneuver: The Pinard maneuver is used in cases of breech presentation to deliver the fetal legs by abducting and flexing the thigh. It is not used during the delivery of the head in a cephalic presentation. C. Lovset maneuver: The Lovset maneuver is also associated with breech delivery. It is used to deliver the fetal arms in a shoulder dystocia situation during a breech birth by rotating the fetal trunk to bring the anterior shoulder under the pubic symphysis. It is not applicable to head delivery in cephalic presentation. D. Maurice-Smellie-Veit maneuver: This maneuver is used in the delivery of the after-coming head in a breech presentation. It involves supporting the fetal body on the forearm, with fingers on the maxilla, and applying suprapubic pressure while traction is applied to the fetal body to encourage head flexion and delivery. It is not used for head delivery in a cephalic presentation.

questions.text: What is the correct sequence of lactation:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Mammogenesis - lactogenesis - galactokinesis - galactopoiesis Mammogenesis refers to the development of the mammary glands, which occurs first. Lactogenesis follows, marking the initiation of milk production. Next is galactokinesis, the process of milk ejection from the mammary glands. Finally, galactopoiesis maintains ongoing milk production. This sequence is crucial for the proper function of lactation, as each stage builds on the previous one to ensure milk production and delivery.

questions.text: A G2P1 with previous C- section with 38 weeks of GA came for delivery, You opted for vaginal birth after C section, which of the following has the least risk in case the previous C- section is of ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A). Transverse incision Explanation: A transverse incision, specifically a low transverse uterine incision, is made in the lower, thinner, and less contractile segment of the uterus. This type of incision is the most common and carries the lowest risk of uterine rupture during a subsequent Vaginal Birth After Cesarean (VBAC), typically less than 1%. The scar in this area is stronger and less likely to dehisce under the stress of labor contractions. Incorrect Options: Option (B). Breech presentation Explanation: Breech presentation refers to the fetal position (baby presenting feet or buttocks first) that led to the previous C-section. While a C-section performed for breech presentation is considered a "non-recurrent" indication (meaning the reason for the C-section is unlikely to recur in subsequent pregnancies, making VBAC more favorable), it does not describe the type of uterine incision. The safety of VBAC is primarily determined by the uterine incision type, not the reason for the previous C-section. Option (C). Classical C section Explanation: A classical C-section involves a vertical incision made in the upper, thicker, and highly contractile part of the uterus. This type of incision carries the highest risk of uterine rupture (around 4-9%) during a subsequent labor due to the high stress on the scar. Therefore, a classical C-section is generally considered a contraindication for VBAC and poses the highest risk among the options. Option (D). Horizontal incision Explanation: The term "horizontal incision" is a general description. While a low transverse uterine incision is horizontal, this option is less precise than "Transverse incision" in the context of C-sections. "Transverse incision" in obstetrics almost universally refers to the low transverse uterine incision, which is the safest. If "Horizontal incision" were to imply something other than the low transverse, it would need further specification. However, assuming it refers to the low transverse, option A (Transverse incision) is the more specific and commonly used term for the safest VBAC incision.

questions.text: In Rh negative pregnant female after performing chorionic sampling dose of anti - D?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 150 microgram In a Rh-negative pregnant female, after procedures like chorionic villus sampling (CVS), it is essential to prevent Rh incompatibility and sensitization. A dose of 150 micrograms of anti-D immunoglobulin is typically given to prevent sensitization to any Rh-positive fetal blood cells that may have entered the maternal circulation. This is the standard dose following invasive procedures such as amniocentesis or chorionic villus sampling. Incorrect Options: B. 50 microgram A 50 microgram dose of anti-D is usually used in other situations, such as during the first trimester for smaller events like early pregnancy loss, but it is not the recommended dose after chorionic villus sampling, which requires a higher dose (150 micrograms). C. 100 microgram A 100 microgram dose is insufficient and not typically used after procedures like CVS. It would not provide the appropriate level of protection for the mother in this scenario. D. 300 microgram A 300 microgram dose is sometimes used in other circumstances, like during delivery of an Rh-positive baby, but it is more than what is required after chorionic villus sampling, where 150 micrograms is the appropriate dose.

questions.text: What is the ideal time to check for Nuchal translucency to diagnose aneuploidy ?

choices.text: Complete mole is made up of 46xx
GTN includes partial mole, complete mole and choriocarcinoma

questions.text: Which of the following statements are correct about gestational trophoblastic disease ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Complete mole is made up of 46XX • Most complete hydatidiform moles are 46XX, formed when a single sperm duplicates its chromosomes after fertilizing an empty ovum (monospermic origin). • Less commonly, it can be 46XY if two sperms fertilize the empty ovum (dispermic). • Importantly, all genetic material is paternal in complete moles. B. Partial mole is monospermic • Partial moles are almost always dispermic — two sperms fertilize a normal ovum, resulting in a triploid karyotype (e.g., 69XXY, 69XXX, or 69XYY). • So partial moles are typically not monospermic. C. GTN includes partial mole, complete mole and choriocarcinoma • Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia (GTN) refers to the malignant or invasive forms of trophoblastic disease. It includes: • Invasive mole • Choriocarcinoma • Placental site trophoblastic tumor (PSTT) • Epithelioid trophoblastic tumor • Partial and complete moles are considered benign and are classified under Gestational Trophoblastic Disease (GTD), not GTN — unless they become invasive. D. It will never be invasive • This is false. A complete mole can become invasive, leading to invasive mole or even progress to choriocarcinoma. • Partial moles rarely become invasive, but complete moles do so in up to 15–20% of cases.
